{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3533610,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T23:14:04.581Z","cooked":"

Hi, I’m running an arm with two neos and one absolute encoder connected to one of the sparkmaxes, right now every time I use setReference, regardless of the given setpoint value, the arm always moves to the position it started at when it turned on. I’m not really sure what is causing this, I tried running a method to reset the arm to a certain starting position when enabled (I added it js now but didn’t make the changes to our github) which didn’t work. Here’s my code: CODE

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T23:14:04.581Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":55,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":307.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"Mohammad Wasim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/frc3624/REEFSCAPE","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - frc3624/REEFSCAPE: FRC Team 3624 code for REEFSCAPE 2025 game","clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3534570,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T19:11:15.467Z","cooked":"

Does the arm move to the setpoint or not move at all?
From rev examples, setReference needs to be called in periodic() and not just initialize() like you have it.
If you need to hold the arm in that position against gravity or other forces, you need to keep calling setReference also.

Your reached boolean would be clearer if expressed as
Math.abs(setpoint -position)<.001;

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T19:17:04.688Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":49.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534776,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T22:18:13.494Z","cooked":"

When we call the command itself the arm will go to the position it started in and stay there. Should I just call the subsystem in robot container with the method and have the position method run in periodic?

Tried testing again, the arm will not go to any set position. This didn’t work when I tried calling the subsystem directly in robot container when a button was toggled and having the setReference command in periodic.

Did you move arm.setPosition(position); to periodic in the realPosition command? You must do that.
Were you getting the debug print statements in realPosition when you set a new value?
Its possible your realPosition is ending immediately because it doesn’t have time to compute with the new setpoint. For a test, make the isFinished() method return false; instead of arm.reached.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T00:15:12.992Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":84,"readers_count":83,"score":26.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68830,"username":"Mohammad1","name":"Mohammad Wasim","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534868,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T00:32:54.461Z","cooked":"

I will try doing that on Saturday (next time the rooms open). As for the print statements it will say that it’s moving when the command is initialized and then immediately stop and say reached.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T00:32:54.461Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"Mohammad Wasim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28240,"username":"icemannie","name":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534894,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T00:55:47.552Z","cooked":"

When you say periodic, do you mean in execute?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T00:55:47.552Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":18.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"Mohammad Wasim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28240,"username":"icemannie","name":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535218,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T13:06:12.194Z","cooked":"

Yes execute()
I’m trying to understand what your Arm looks like and what it does. You have a position command and a Spin command. Arms don’t normally spin. Side issue the setSpeed method sets both leader and follower. Only leader is needed.
In periodic in the subsystem there are SmartDashboard putNumbers for setpoint and position.

What values does the encoder.getPosition show if you turn the arm by hand when disabled?
What values show after a new setpoint command?
You have an encoder position conversion factor of 1. Does this mean both motors are connected direct to the arm with no mechanical reductions? It looks like it from the setpoint numbers you use. A picture would help understand what you are doing,
How did you arrive at the pid gains for the arm?
For debug, add the following to periodic in the subsystem.

SmartDashboard.putNumber("Leader Volts", leader.getAppliedOutput()*RobotController.getBatteryVoltage());
SmartDashboard.putNumber("Leader Amps", leader.getOutputCurrent());
SmartDashboard.putNumber("Follower Volts", follower.getAppliedOutput()*RobotController.getBatteryVoltage());
SmartDashboard.putNumber("Follower Amps", follower.getOutputCurrent());

Start AdvantageScope from the VSCode Start Tool
Do File ConnectToRobot and you’ll see all the SmartDashboard values. You can pull them onto a LineGraph and see them in real time like an oscilloscope. It’ll give a better understanding of what’s happening

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T15:45:23.159Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":17.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68830,"username":"Mohammad1","name":"Mohammad Wasim","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535350,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T16:06:54.611Z","cooked":"

Sry we’re bad at naming things, the spin command is used so the driver can rotate the arm on their own by holding either the right or left trigger. Our arm works with two Neo motors attached to two sprockets (on opposite ends) which is connected via two chains to two larger sprockets that control the arm. We didn’t think we needed to put in a conversion factor because the absolute through bore encoder is connected straight to the shaft that controls the arm itself and not the motor, would we still need to put in the conversion factor? I will be in the room tomorrow and I’ll try the debugging tips you suggested, from what I remember smart dashboard showed the right values of the encoder when the arm reached certain positions when rotated manually (I compared it with the values shown on the rev client). I got the pid values from tuning the arms movements when it would only go to the position it started at when turned on every time I would call the command when I first tried it.

IMG_25601179×2556 4.47 MB

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T16:06:54.611Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":46,"readers_count":45,"score":14.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"Mohammad Wasim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28240,"username":"icemannie","name":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535409,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T17:09:34.488Z","cooked":"

Better way to control an arm is to use a combination of feedforward and pid.
See Controllers — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

Then you need to scale.
Will pid alone work? Yes but slower and less accurate.
What accuracy do you need from your arm and how fast do you want it to reach its set points?
If you crunch through your chaines and sprocket numbers, how fast can it move in degrees per second? How much backlash is there?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T17:09:34.488Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":36,"readers_count":35,"score":17.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/controllers/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Controllers — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68830,"username":"Mohammad1","name":"Mohammad Wasim","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535678,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T20:10:16.672Z","cooked":"

We want our arm to get to its positions as accurately as possible, we prefer it to move fast but the arm has a considerable amount of backlash (most noticeable when placed on a table, one time it nearly tipped over, which is why we added a ramp rate, we want the pid controller to have the arm accelerate and decelerate as it reaches the desired position. With the documentation you just sent us are you suggesting we use the wpilib pid controller and set a voltage to the motor? I’m new to pid and how it works but would just setting the voltage to the motor based on the .calculate() method cause it to speed up and slow down as it gets closer to the desired position or would the motor move at a constant calculated velocity and stop when reached?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T20:10:16.672Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":32,"readers_count":31,"score":6.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"Mohammad Wasim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28240,"username":"icemannie","name":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535680,"name":"Mohammad Wasim","username":"Mohammad1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b5ac83/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T20:11:39.911Z","cooked":"

I’ll have to look at the sprocket sizes to tell you it’s speed in degrees per second, I’ll get back to you soon with that

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T20:11:39.911Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":29,"readers_count":28,"score":10.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492380,"topic_slug":"arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position","display_username":"Mohammad Wasim","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28240,"username":"icemannie","name":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68830,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/arm-closed-loop-control-going-to-same-position/492380/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535737,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T20:53:11.124Z","cooked":"

You need to minimize backlash. With any backlash, then you shouldn’t be using the absolute encoder as feedback in your position loop. It should be used to preset the motor encoder on startup, and then the position loop should be closed around it. That way there is no backlash inside the position loop. You can also use always reach the endpoint in the up direction by intentionally overshooting on the way down and then moving up again.

The way to run it is using trapezoid pid with feedforward. When a new position is commanded it ramps the speed up and also closes the pid loop. Arm feedforward has three constants, one of which is the gravity constant. Internally it looks at the angle of the arm and adjusts the power to the motor using a cosine function so it will apply max when the arm is level and zero when it is at 90 degrees.

Adding to the above response: If precision is important and/or backlash is severe, you’ll want to account for it when you sync your absolute and relative encoders. If you don’t, your “relative encoder” position will be off by +/- backlash compared to the absolute encoder.

This can be done on boot by hand if you can turn the motor and preset the gearing in a consistent manner.

In code, you can do this by applying small motor output before running your sync operation.

If you need a reference example, we have this one from last year. We set the initial position on boot, and then at the start of our auto, ran a “calibrate” routine that set it again with the backlash managed.
https://github.com/stormbots/Crescendo/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/CalibrateShooter.java

Use ArmFeedforward instead of SimpleFeedforward. It adds in a voltage to compensate for the difference in gravity effect caused by the robot angle.

This thread goes through a lot of things you can use, even though it is for an elevator. Elevator PID Tuning Issues with Gravity - #30 by Oblarg

Look for posts covering how to get ks, kg and kv values.

The end of motion is need to signal that next actions should continue. Your arm will fall if you don’t keep the position loop closed all the time.
